newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ wine exports jump 26 percent in 1996/97.
newsitem.headline: NZ wine exports jump 26 percent in 1996/97.

text.p: New Zealand wine exports grew 26 percent in value to NZ$75.9 million for the year to 30 June, 1997, the Wine Institute of New Zealand said on Thursday.
The volume of exports was up 19 percent to 13.1 million litres.
In 1995/96 wine exports totalled 11 million litres worth $60.3 million. The value of exports has risen from $18 million in 1991.

"The growth is the result of the industry's investment in long term market development, and the increased availability of wine from the 1995 and 1996 vintages," institute chief executive Philip Gregan said.

Britain remains the major market for New Zealand wine, taking 8.1 million litres of wine valued at $47.1 million in 1996/97. This compares with 7.4 million litres and $40.6 million in the previous year.

However, the fastest growth occurred in markets such as the United States, Germany and Australia. Exports to the United States rose 170 percent in 1996/97 to 508,000 litres, and to Australia the increase was 41 percent to 1.6 million litres.
Bottled wine exports to Germany also increased rapidly, jumping more than 200 percent over the previous year.
Gregan said the 10 percent fall of the New Zealand dollar against the U.S. dollar since November should give the industry a further fillip.
"The fall hasn't impacted much this year. The fall in the dollar should boost returns over the next year if it keeps down," Gregan said.
Exports had been concentrated in Britain because of a shortage of available wine.
"We have been far more successful in the U.K. market than we ever imagined we would be and we haven't had the supply to develop other markets," Gregan said.
"There has been no use developing other markets up until now because we haven't had the grapes to supply."
Exports are projected to rise 20 percent per annum as wine planting increases to 83,000 hectares in two years from 73,000 in 1997.
The institute expects annual exports to be more than $125 million by the turn of the century.
New Zealand expects to further develop its markets in the United States, Australia, Germany and The Netherlands.
